title: Musk Gives Twitter’s Board an Expensive Out
sub_head: Board’s fiduciary duty would argue against taking opening, nonbinding bid at weak point for the stock
body:
Some say money means never having to say you’re sorry. It also apparently means never having to entertain the indignity of a counteroffer.
Elon Musk’s offer to buy Twitter—made in a terse letter to Twitter Chairman Bret Taylor on Wednesday—reflects such thinking. The per-share price of $54.20 reflects a 51% premium over the stock’s 30-day average before Mr. Musk first reporting his interest in the company on April 4. It’s also 24% below what the stock was fetching less than a year ago, meaning the offer would normally—and rightfully—be considered an opener.
